description: Erection of single storey side and rear extension; and removal of existing chimney
decision_conditions: The roof of the extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The materials and finishes of the external walls and window frames of the development hereby permitted shall match in colour and texture those of the existing building, or such other materials as shall have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority and shall thereafter be retained as such. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the western flank wall of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises semi-detached dwelling on Park Road.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. - Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:  While the proposed single storey rear/side extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of set-back from the front wall of the original house by at least 500mm and the depth of 6 meters (4m from the neighbouring extension), officers note that it would be designed to respect the character of the original dwelling, and would appear a subordinate to the host property. Although the proposed first floor rear extension would be visible from Parkfields Road, it would to relate well to the main property and would generally follow the guidelines set out in the Residential Design SPD. Therefore, officers consider that on balance there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted Fire Safety information, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.14 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed two storey side extension would not strictly comply with the requirements set out in the Residential Design SPD as the proposal would not be set back at first floor level, and would not be adequately set down from the ridge line or in from the shared boundary. However, given that an element of separation would be maintained between the neighbouring property, officers consider that the proposal would not break down the characteristic gaps within the immediate surrounding area. Further, given that the proposal would be a modest width, propose materials to match the existing dwelling and would be somewhat set down from the ridge line, officers consider that the proposal would appear a proportionate addition to the host property. Given that similar extensions are viewed within the immediate vicinity, officers consider that the proposal would not detract from the character and appearance of the area.The proposed single storey front extension would adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD and as such, is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed single storey rear extension would extend slightly further in depth than what is recommended by the Residential Design SPD, but would propose an appropriate roof form, and modest height, and as such, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the host property or surrounding area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the modest scale and siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, and that the adjoining property benefits from an existing rear extension, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. While an opening is proposed to the north-west elevation at first floor, TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would involve the conversion of the existing garage into habitable space. While this is contrary to the recommendations set out in the Sustainable Transport SPD, officers note that the host property benefits from hardstanding to the front of the property and as such would be able to accommodate on-street parking. London Plan policy T5 requires all development to include provision for cycle parking. Given that the proposal would include the loss of the existing garage, officers consider it appropriate to impose a condition to ensure that cycle parking is provided in the event of an approval.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The submitted plan and elevations have an incorrect scale bar. Please submit the plan and elevations with the correct scale bar.Note: Please provide plan and elevations at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of entire plan and elevation, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.

The scale bar in the submitted proposed elevations do not measure to the stated scale.Please provide copies of all proposed elevations at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.
